message: THIS WEEK IN CONGRSS - December 30, 2016

Sablan sworn in to 115th US Congress   Washington, D.C. – Congressman Gregorio Kilili Camacho Sablan took the oath of office along with 439 other Members of the U.S. House of Representatives on Tuesday. Congressman Sablan begins his fifth term as the representative of the people of the Northern Mariana Islands in Congress. Accompanying the Congressman for a ceremonial photograph with House Speaker Paul Ryan at the U.S. Capitol were Mr. James Fleming, Ms. Edith Deleon Guerrero, Ms. Edz Villagomez, Ms. Regina Kautz, Mr. Bernard Cabrera, Ms. Andrea Sablan, Ms. Jude Marfil, Ms. Beberty Bacani, Mr. Edward Pangelinan, and Mr. Robert Schwalbach. Congressman Sablan placed his hand upon the Bible first given to him for this purpose in 2009 by the Most Reverend Tomas A. Camacho, now-retired Bishop of the Diocese of Chalan Kanoa.
Thirty strong, my fifth term membership in the Congressional Hispanic Caucus.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - January 6, 2017

In my 8 years in office, our relationship with Mr. Kanazawa, Joe Diego and colleagues is one of the best.  I ran into Mr. Kanazawa at a meeting in Washington DC and asked him if he could improve USDA Rural Development services to the Northern Marianas.  He promised to do so and he has kept his promise.  I thank Mr. Kanazawa and his colleagues for their hard and good work for the Northern Marianas.  He shall be missed by many.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - January 13, 2017

The first - 2017 - Northern Marianas Veterans Resources Fair will be held on Rota, Tinian and Saipan.  Times, dates, and venues are provided in the banner below.  If you are a veteran, a military family or an active member of the uniformed services, you are welcome to attend.  Exhibitors will include the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, VA Choice Providers, Northern Marianas Government, Nonprofits and Private Institutions.  The event is free.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - January 19, 2017
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS -  January 27, 2017

Staff Assistant – Congressman Gregorio Kilili Camacho Sablan is seeking a Staff Assistant in the Washington, D.C. congressional office. Responsibilities include answering phones, maintaining the front office, greeting visitors and giving Capitol tours, answering constituent requests for general information, assisting the office manager with scheduling and bookkeeping, and assisting staff with other various administrative and legislative duties in a supportive role. The Assistant will also be responsible for selecting books at the Library of Congress for the Congressman’s “Let’s Read” initiative.  Excellent writing, verbal and organizational skills are essential. Candidates should be well-organized, hard-working, detail oriented, and willing to learn. High degree of professionalism required, as well as an ability to work a flexible schedule. Ties to the Northern Mariana Islands preferred.  Qualified candidates should submit a cover letter, resume and two writing samples to bob.schwalbach@mail.house.gov. No phone calls or drop-ins, please.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - Febraury 3, 2017
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - February 17, 2017

The first Northern Marianas Veterans Resources Fair begins today on Saipan, February 22, 1pm - 7pm at the Multipurpose Center.  Veterans, active service members, and military families are encouraged to attend. Exhibitors will include the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, VA Choice Providers, Northern Marianas Government, Nonprofits and Private Institutions. The event is free and open to the public.

The Northern Marianas Veterans Resource Fair continues on Tinian today, Thursday, February 23 at the NMC Instructional Site, 10am to 4pm. Veterans, service members, and military families are encouraged to attend. The event is free.

For veterans, service members, and military families - the Northern Marianas Veterans Resource Fair will be on Rota today, Friday, February 24 at the Rota Resort from 10am to 4pm. The event is free and open to the public. This is the third and final day of the fair.

Customs and Border Protection Officers – Customs and Border Protection has openings for Customs and Border Protection Officers in Saipan. CBP Officers are members of the Federal Law Enforcement Officer profession. Typical assignments include enforcing customs, immigration, and agriculture law and regulations; facilitating the flow of legitimate trade and travel; and conducting inspections of individuals and conveyances. Position is open until March 31, 2017. For more information, go to https://www.usajobs.gov/GetJob/ViewDetails/464524600/ and https://www.usajobs.gov/GetJob/ViewDetails/464772000/.

Excellent writing, verbal and organizational skills are essential. Ties to the Northern Mariana Islands preferred. Compliments of KSPN2 TV.
Speaking on the floor on bill to name the AS Veterans Clinic the Faleomavaega Eni Hunkin Center in honor of my former colleague and friend.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - March 10, 2017

Lejeune vets get toxin presumption  The rule, presuming that anyone who served in the military at Camp Lejeune between 1953 and 1987 was exposed to toxic drinking water, went into effect on March 14. Some members of the military, the reserve, and the National Guard stationed at the Marine Corps base in North Carolina during those years have subsequently been diagnosed with adult leukemia, myelodysplastic syndromes including aplastic anemia, cancer of the bladder, kidney and liver, multiple myeloma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, or Parkinson’s disease. Under the new rule, these servicemembers may be eligible for disability benefits. To apply servicemembers must provide records showing at least 30 days of service at Camp Lejeune or MCAS New River, including satellite camps and housing areas, and medical diagnosis of one of the eight covered diseases.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - March 17, 2017

Deputy Secretary of Defense Robert Work met with me at the Pentagon on Friday.  I explained to him the negative feelings the people of Tinian have about the proposed live-fire training on their island—a feeling I share.  I also expressed my personal opposition to any bombing of Pagan.  We discussed the importance of the Republic of Palau to America’s defense posture in the Pacific, too, and the need to renew Palau’s Compact of Free Association.

Workplace injuries in the Marianas spiked last year (see chart below), including a broken back and two amputations, and 80 serious injuries reported from construction sites in the Northern Marianas.  I met this week with Tom Gallassi, Director of Enforcement Programs (second from left) and other U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration officials to find out what OSHA is doing to prevent these injuries and take action against employers who fail to follow safety rules.  With a worker falling to his death this week, clearly more needs to be done.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - March 24, 2017

The congressional office met with USCIS officials yesterday and among the several things brought up that we can discuss at this time is the question about delivery of applications to the California Service Center.   If you want to submit your upcoming CW applications in person with a start date of Oct. 1, 2017 can you deliver them in person to the Processing Center in Laguna Niguel, California?    Beginning Monday, April 3, 2017, USCIS will begin accepting petitions subject to the Fiscal Year 2018 CW-1 cap.  CW-1 petitions can be either mailed or delivered via courier or express delivery to the USCIS California Service Center using the following addresses:   For Form I-129CW petitions, please use the following address:  California Service Center P.O. Box 10698 Laguna Niguel, CA 92607-1098.   For Form I-129CW petitions delivered via courier or express delivery, please use following address:  California Service Center 24000 Avila Road, 2nd Floor, Room 2312 Laguna Niguel, CA 92677.  Please note that your petition may NOT be filed by showing up in-person at the California Service Center.

THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - April 7, 2017

Happily strengthened by our faith in this Holy Week of Easter and Passover, I hope you are enjoying renewal in the love of family and friends and in the spirit of the Risen Christ.   Thank you People of the Northern Mariana for the inspiration that you are.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - April 17, 2017

Veterans Choice Program Extended  Veterans can keep using the Veterans Choice program to see private doctors in the Northern Marianas. Choice was scheduled to end on August 7, but President Trump signed The Veterans Choice Program Improvement Act on Wednesday extending the program until early 2018. Veterans will no longer be responsible for paying the private provider. The new law makes the Veterans Administration the primary payer. The Act also makes record-sharing between the VA and outside doctors easier. The Veterans Choice program has already expanded access to care for veterans. Now, the extension gives Congress time to work on more ways to allow veterans to get the help they need outside of the VA system. I look forward to working with my colleagues on the House Veterans Affairs Committee to ensure more choice for veterans, especially those in the Marianas.

Joeten-Kiyu Public Library; Saipan Southern High School; the CNMI Association of Archives, Libraries and Museums; St. Jude Renal Care Facility; and the Commonwealth Healthcare Corporation’s Hemodialysis Center all received books this week. We are celebrating National Library Month by delivering books from the Library of Congress Surplus Books Program—over a hundred boxes so far this month alone. Let’s Read!  Congratulations as well to Joeten-Kiyu Public Library, which unveiled its new Bookmobile, made possible by a $25,000 Rural Development grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and $54,000 from the Commonwealth government. The Bookmobile features a taller roof, more floor space for books, and sturdier wheels to allow for more village outreach. (L-R) Library Council Secretary Dencio Manglona; Library Council Acting Chair Asap Ogumoro; Library Director Erlinda Naputi; and USDA Rural Development Area Manager Joseph Diego, with over a dozen students and library patrons in the Bookmobile.

Social Security up in 2016  The number of Social Security recipients in the Marianas is growing as is the amount of money that Social Security brings into our economy each year. Data for 2016 was released this week. There are now 1,839 retired or disabled workers, as well as 1,039 widows and widowers, parents, spouses and children of workers, receiving social security assistance. The amount is based on each recipient’s lifetime earning and averages about $7,714 per year. Benefits for all Marianas recipients in 2016 totaled $22.2 million. This is an increase of $1.3 million over 2015 as 128 beneficiaries have been added to the rolls. In addition, another 1,044 low-income persons, who are aged, blind, or disabled, are eligible for Supplemental Security Income, or SSI, 11 more than in 2015. SSI brings $7.6 million into our local economy. This data is available at www.ssa.gov/policy/docs/factsheets/cong_stats/2016/mp.html.

Earth Day  Today, April 22 is Earth Day, the annual celebration of environmental stewardship that began in 1970 and is credited with starting the modern environmental movement. We should all be concerned with current efforts to dismantle the work of Republicans and Democrats over the last 47 years—work that has resulted in cleaner air and water and made the Earth safer for all living beings. This week I cosponsored a resolution to recognize Earth Day and encourage environmental education and activism.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - April 21, 2017

This effort started in 2012.  And after a long wait for the SNAP-like pilot program to be implemented in the Northern Marianas, FNS advised me this week that my work to include language in the FARMM bill providing a pilot program with over $30 million, in addition to the annual $12 million block grant funds, is finally expected to begin either June or July, 2017. FNS reported that they are now just about done putting final touches to the program.  I thank Governor Torres, Mr. Robert Hunter, Mr. Walter Macaranas, Region IX FNS Administrator Mr. Jesus Mendoza and his team, Mr. Scott Carter, Director of FNS headquarters' congressional affairs for their leadership, and to our many dedicated NAP staff for their long and hard work developing the program so it is ready to implement.  I also give special mention to my former congressional office colleague Mr. Ed H. Manglona for months of hard work working with me to get our legislation to pass Congress and signed into law.  I am saddened that our former governor, the late Eloy S. Inos, who was a strong supporter of this program from the start, is not with us to witness the start of the program.  We need this program to begin in earnest because we need to gather data that we can use to justify extending this Pilot Program in the FARMM bill reauthorization legislation that is expected to be considered in the Agriculture Committee sometime later this year or early next year.  And I need to find funds for FNS and NAP to implement the EBT cards in the Northern Marianas.  Most importantly, we need this improved program so that families, including some 6,000 children, who are eligible for food assistance could see some increase to their benefits while also safeguarding against program fraud. Changing the program's eligibility guidelines will also allow those individuals who work full time and receive assistance, to probably not lose eligibility even if their earnings increases with the minimum wage increases scheduled for September of 2017 and 2018.   These individuals could continue to work full-time while also remaining eligible to receive help feeding their families.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - April 28, 2017

I prefer that Congress passes the 12 separate appropriation bills under regular order. But reaching agreement on how to fund the federal government for the five months remaining in the fiscal year is still very good news.  Stay tune for more details once the bill is distributed today or tomorrow.
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - May

Greetings,  I have always said that our people are our most important resources, and educating and training them for the workforce is the most important investment we can do for all of us.  A rock solid education puts our children on a path to success, and our schoolteachers play a critical role in helping our children learn and grow.  Which is why education remains my top priority in Congress.  And my ranking member position in a House Education and the Workforce Subcommittee gives me a seat at the table, and a top seat on the dais to question and seek solutions on important issues facing our public and private schools.  I visited several schools this month again and I met with students, teachers, school administrators and PSS Commissioner of Education Deleon Guerrero and some of her leadership team.  During this National Teacher Appreciation Week, I am writing to express how truly inspired I am by the teachers of the Northern Marianas and their dedication to our students.  The change of leadership in the new Federal government administration makes the road ahead challenging, especially since the new administration has approved laws which provide less transparency in teacher preparation programs, ensure less diversity in our teaching workforce, and weaken oversight from the Department of Education to ensure a quality education for every student.   As your Delegate and as a ranking member of a subcommittee of the House Education and the Workforce Committee I will continue to fight so all of our children have access to a quality education.  And that begins by standing with the teachers who are committed to excellence for our students.   I hope that you will join me in supporting our teachers and all our schools during this National Teacher Appreciation Week.  Let a teacher know that you appreciate what they do to help mold our future through the education and training of our children – their students.  A huge thank you goes out to all teachers for their dedication in shaping our Commonwealth's future through the education and training of their students.  Thank you!  Kilili
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - May 12, 2017
This is an exceptional opportunity for one of our Marianas veterans to branch out into a new field of endeavor, while still serving his or her country. – Congressman Kilili
THIS WEEK IN CONGRESS - May 19, 2017

Human trafficking preys on the most vulnerable in society. I have seen firsthand some terrible cases of this scourge in recent months as certain companies lured foreign workers to come to the Northern Marianas through false promises and misrepresentations, withheld their pay and passports, and subjected them to horrible working and living conditions.  I applaud Chairman Walberg’s leadership on this issue and look forward to working with him to make sure that the Department of Labor has the tools and resources they need to combat human trafficking. -- Congressman Kilili
On this Memorial Day and every day, we should never forget the servicemen and women who died in service to keep our country safe.  Nor should we forget their families.

A 2012 Obama Administration executive order that prodded a three-week visa processing timeline for non-immigrant visas has been canceled by a Trump Administration executive order.  While most consular interviews are for tourist visas, the new directive will also affect employment visas such as visas for CW petitions that have been approved by Homeland Security but are required to undergo consular interviews for visas to enter the U.S. (i.e. the Northern Marianas).

The Exchange is excited to welcome Veterans of all United States Armed Forces as part of the Veterans online shopping benefit. They will soon be able to serve veterans through the lifelong shopping privileges they have rightfully earned.  There is even free standard shipping to the Northern Mariana Islands (96950, 96951, 96952) zip codes when a veterans online purchase totals $49 or more. (Some conditions apply to the free standard shipping.)  The first step is check your eligibility. Go to VetVerify.org and submit your verification form today.

If you are a federal government employee, then you should read this.  • The Trump administration fiscal year 2018 budget would cost federal employees and retirees, cumulatively, hundreds of thousands of dollars over the course of retirement, and reneges on the commitments made to our nation’s dedicated public servants, who were promised their retirement benefits in exchange for hard work over long careers. • The president’s budget proposes to eliminate or reduce cost-of-living adjustments (COLAs) for current and future retirees under the Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS) and the Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS). • The president’s budget proposes to increase FERS employees’ contributions to their annuities by 1 percent each year for the next six years, without any corresponding benefit increase. This amounts to nothing more than a 6 percent pay cut. • The president’s budget proposes to change the calculation for federal pensions to be based on the average of the highest five years of salary instead of the current highest three, which particularly hurts those closest to retirement. • The FERS Annuity Supplement would be eliminated for new retirees starting in fiscal year 2018. • These proposals would diminish the value of federal annuities, threaten the financial security of those just years away from retiring, and generally reduce the quality of life of our nation’s employees and retirees.  Modify Postal Reform Legislation (H.R. 756) (for those who are employees of the U.S. Postal Services)  • Leading postal reform legislation would require all current and future postal retirees to enroll in Medicare and pay additional premiums for that coverage or forfeit their retiree health benefits. • Current postal retirees should retain the choice as to whether to add Medicare to their retiree health benefit coverage. Eliminating that choice breaks a basic promise not to change health benefits in retirement, and increases costs for those on a fixed income. • This legislation would result in a $10.7 billion cost shift to Medicare.  Those who have a Thrifty Savings Plan (the federal government equivalent to a 401k account) should know important changes in the TSP Modernization Act (S. 873/H.R. 3031)  • The TSP Modernization Act (S. 873/H.R. 3031) would expand and create more flexible withdrawal options for Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) participants. • TSP participants have experienced an overly restrictive set of withdrawal rules since the beginning of the TSP 30 years ago, causing participants to transfer their retirement accounts out of the TSP and into higher-fee accounts in exchange for additional options. • The bill would create more options for participants before and during retirement, providing participants increased financial independence and encouraging them to keep their money in the TSP. • This legislation has been approved by committee in each chamber and should be passed by the full House and Senate without delay.

I have received several inquiries about the situation with North Korea. For now, I can say that we have no reason for alarm although North Korea’s actions is escalating tensions in our region.  I have also received an invitation to attend a Classified (TS-SCI) Briefing on September 6, 2017 (EDT).  The briefing team will comprise of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, Secretary of Defense James Mattis, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff General Joseph Dunford Jr. and Director of National Intelligence Director Dan Coats.  I am prohibited from sharing those parts of the briefing that are Classified (TS-SCI) but I will be able to have an updated understanding of the situation.  And the part(s) of the briefing that I am allowed to share, I shall do almost immediately following the briefing, hopefully by late morning of September 7, 2017 (ChST).  But the best information we have at the present time gives me no cause for alarm. There are ongoing background discussions with our allies that are intended to deescalate the tensions.

Two months into the new Enhanced Nutrition Assistance Program (E-NAP) that increases benefits and makes more people eligible for food stamps, Food and Nutrition Services Regional Administrator Jesus Mendoza (far right) updated me on progress. Not everyone who is now eligible for the increased assistance has applied, Mendoza said, and more public education on the new benefits is needed. I included $33.5 million in the 2014 Agricultural Act , so more people at lower income levels could get help feeding their families and so that benefits in the Marianas could be closer to those on Guam. The money became available on July 1. Check with the CNMI NAP office on the new income thresholds.

H visa provisions, affecting the Marianas, in the National Defense Authorization Act were on the agenda, when newly-confirmed Assistant Secretary of Defense Lucian Niemeyer (on my left) met with me on Thursday. The NDAA will be a top priority when Congress resumes in September. We also discussed the importance of funding the Palau Compact extension in this year’s Act and agreed to meet again in Washington after Niemeyer completes his Pacific tour.

Marine Corps veteran Randy Takai Johnson was selected for a Wounded Warrior Congressional Fellowship. He begins his two-year fellowship, working with the congressional office, in September. Mr. Johnson served from 2003-2007, including two tours in Iraq as a combat engineer, detecting improvised explosive devices and participating in various combat operations. He earned the Purple Heart for wounds received in the line of duty. After completing a Bachelor of Science in Information Technology in 2014, Randy returned home to the Marianas. He has been working for the Northern Marianas Chapter of the American Red Cross, assisting the recovery from Typhoon Soudelor and coordinating the Chapter’s data system. Randy has a passion for public service, and looks forward to assisting fellow veterans and their families in the Marianas through his work. Welcome, Randy.

Wounded Warrior Fellow Randy Johnson is already getting up-to-speed on the work we are doing in the Marianas for our veterans. On Thursday, I introduced Mr. Johnson (on my left) at the Veterans Benefits Workshop and Claims Clinic, which, as a member of the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee, I requested be held. Mr. Eric Gaskin and Mr. Kalani Echang from the VA conducted the workshop and one-on-one-benefits counseling sessions. Also participating was Mr. Oscar Torres, Executive Director for the Commonwealth Military/Veterans Affairs Office, which assists veterans with their claims.

“We love books,” says Kagman High School Librarian Maria Ornes; and this week we delivered 9 boxes of new books to add to the Kagman collection. Your congressional office staff handpick these books from the extra copies submitted to the Library of Congress by book publishers. We tailor our selections to match the readers, whether elementary, high school, or adult. Over the last nine years, your congressional office has sent about 40,000 books to libraries, youth and senior centers, and other locations in the Marianas. Thank you Ms. Ornes, Ms. Halstead, Principal Staffler, and Ayuyus. A-Y-U-Y-U! A-Y-U-Y-U! A-Y-U-Y-U!

This Monday, September 11, 2017, marks the 16th anniversary of the tragic attacks of our country. As a day of remembrance and service, I will join other Democratic members of the House Veterans Affairs Committee to a five-hour offsite visit to Walter Reed’s National Medical Center spending time with injured service members and touring the facilities the Department of Defense uses to rehabilitate and care for them.  Our visit will include touring the National Intrepid Center of Excellence, John P. Murtha Cancer Center and the Orthopedics and Rehabilitation units.  I ask our Northern Marianas communities to please spend a moment of silent thought and prayer for all those who have been injured or maimed or who perished in the tragic attack and in the ongoing war against terror. Keep our veterans and military families, and all our first responders and recovery workers in your prayers on this 16th anniversary of the horrific day when our country was attacked.

Maggie Untalan, Halina Palacios, Maxine Pangelinan, Jolyn Attao, and Zinna Agulto (l-r) visited their congressional office on Tuesday. We also arranged for them to tour the White House and the United States Capitol. The Commonwealth Healthcare Corporation staff members were in Washington, DC to attend the 2017 Maternal, Infant, and Early Childhood Home Visiting All Grantee Meeting.

Looking ahead on the workforce: Now that a short-term fix to Marianas workforce issues has been signed into U.S. Public Law 115-53 by President Trump, the congressional working group that helped draft that legislation will turn to a long-term policy. The goals are to ensure the Marianas economy has a sufficient workforce after the 2019 end of the current Commonwealth-only Transitional Worker (CW) program and to keep improving the ratio of U.S. to foreign workers. I met with Mr. Isaac Edwards of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee Republican staff on Friday to plan the way forward.

I joined my colleagues in the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus at a reception Thursday evening honoring the new Members of our growing caucus.  Our group now stands at 64 strong, an indication of the expanding Asian American and Pacific Islander political clout across our nation. At center are Chair Judy Chu from California and Vice-Chair Madeleine Bordallo of Guam.

Workplace safety is key to getting more U.S. workers into the labor force. So I advocated for more funding for Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) enforcement in the Pacific, during debate on the FY18 omnibus spending bill on Tuesday. The Republican majority blocked my amendment, but I will keep fighting for worker safety in the Marianas.

Last October, veterans and military family members in the Marianas were able to take part in a program led by the Northern Marianas Humanities Council that included a screening of the award-winning documentary Almost Sunrise and a special meditation and resilience training that is featured in the film. Almost Sunrise follows two Iraq War veterans as they walk from Wisconsin to California in their quest for healing from the moral wounds of war. The congressional office helped connect the Humanities Council with the filmmakers and workshop trainers from Project Welcome Home last year, and plans are underway to offer the film screening and training once again. This Veterans Day, Almost Sunrise will be aired nationwide on PBS, and director Michael Collins and producer Marty Syjuco are now working on a companion piece that will highlight the outreach campaign in the Marianas. On Tuesday, I sat down with them to discuss the challenges facing veterans and military families in our islands, and the impact the film and workshop had in the Marianas.

To commemorate the September 11 terrorist attacks, Democratic members of the House Veterans Affairs Committee visited veterans recuperating at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center to thank them for their service. Doctors and staff also briefed the Members on the medical and mental health treatments our wounded service members and veterans are receiving.

Service Academy Night starts tonight on Saipan at American Memorial Park Visitors Center, 5-7pm. Free workshops for interested high school and college students, their parents, and educators, featuring presentations by congressional staff and special guests.

Myrtle Cascabel and Helly Montes visited their congressional office in Washington, DC on Wednesday. Ms. Cascabel and Ms. Montes, who both work at City Trust Bank on Saipan, also toured the White House while in the nation’s capital this week. Thank you for visiting.

Coast Guard Academy graduates LT Christine Igisomar and LT Jonathan Girot and Army LTC Lawrence Camacho, who oversees Drexel University’s military science and Army ROTC programs, answered questions from students, parents, and educators about the academy opportunity on Rota, Tinian, and Saipan this week. Also, providing video testimonials were current Air Force Academy cadets Jordan Butcher and Eufemio Feria and West Point graduate, 2LT Thomas Lee. Thanks to all. In 2009, I was able to have legislation enacted making two positions each available for the Marianas at the Air Force, Navy, and Army academies; and in 2015 we increased that to three. For the coming school year, there are five vacancies available: two at West Point, one at the Naval Academy, one at the Air Force Academy, and one at the Merchant Marine Academy. For more information contact the congressional office at 323-2647, email kilili@mail.house.gov, or visit www.sablan.house.gov.

Because I was in the Marianas when my bill, H.R. 339, was signed into law last month, Mr. Alexander Angelson of the White House Office of Legislative Affairs was kind enough to bring me the pen that President Trump used for the occasion. Alex also brought a “red-line,” the formal copy of the law to add to the collection of legislation benefiting the Marianas that I have had enacted—part of which is behind us in this photo. H.R. 339 made more CW permits available, protected established businesses hurt by the surge of construction workers using up the permits, and increased funds to train local workers.

We need common-sense gun reform. Former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords, herself a survivor of a mass shooting, took the podium, as I joined other Democratic Caucus members on the steps of the U.S. Capitol this week to mourn the victims of gun violence in Las Vegas and all over America and demand action. Almost 12,000 people have died this year in the United States from acts of gun violence. It is an epidemic. We need to stop the deaths.

The Northern Marianas is the only U.S. jurisdiction without a VA clinic, dedicated VA medical or mental health professionals, or a Vet Center. Our veterans have to travel to Guam or Hawaii to receive basic medical care. The VA must do more for the veterans in the Northern Marianas who served our country with honor and distinction. Veterans in the Pacific territories are entitled to the benefits they earned and should be able to access those benefits where they live. – Congressman Kilili

Getting ready to start  the Men's Walk Against Violence in Dandan. This is my ninth year to join this annual walk in support of safe families in the Marianas. Liz Balajadia, Benette Seman, and Tina Inos stopped by their congressional office while in Washington, DC on Tuesday. Thank you, all, for visiting.

Imagine serving with honor in the U.S. military, then being deported, unable to access the veterans benefits you earned. That is the case for vets I met in Mexico last weekend. Their service made them automatically eligible for citizenship, but they did not know they still had to apply to become a U.S. citizen. When they did not and later were convicted of a crime, they were deported. Now, they do not have access to the medical care and other benefits all veterans are entitled to. Together with the four other members of the House Veterans Affairs Committee I traveled with, we intend to help these vets who served our country.

“Many of our veterans must travel off-island, sometimes at their own expense, to get the care they need. The oversight hearing that I am calling for, along with my colleagues [Radewagen] and [Bordallo] would help shine a spotlight on the unique challenges veterans in the islands face in accessing the services and benefits they have earned,”  “We also lack any full-time Veterans Benefits Administration staff to help veterans get their benefits. These are deficits that cannot be ignored,”
Thank you for visiting.

We would like to welcome our new Staff Assistant, John Del Rosario, to our D.C. office. John is from Saipan, where he recently taught English, music and journalism at his alma mater Mount Carmel School. Government has been a part of his DNA even at a young age when he was a senator in the CNMI Youth Congress. A graduate of the University of Texas at El Paso with a degree in journalism, he served as administrative aide to Rep. Peter Svarzbein of El Paso’s District 1. He is excited to put his skills to use, now for the people of the CNMI.

Scott Carter, Chief of the Office of Government Affairs at the Agriculture Department’s Food and Nutrition Service, met with me on Thursday to discuss the E-NAP program in the Marianas. E-NAP is using the $32.5 million I added to the 2014 Agricultural Act to make more people eligible for food stamps and raise benefits on Saipan, Tinian, and Rota. Scott also served as a Congressional Fellow here at the office during my first term.

Rep. Frank Lucas (R-Oklahoma) was Chairman of the Agriculture Committee, when I served there, and helped me add $32.5 million to the Marianas food stamp grant. Thursday, I updated him on how the money is paying for a computerized eligibility system and, eventually, electronic swipe cards to replace paper food stamps. Mr. Lucas visited Saipan in 2014 and helped cut the ribbon at the opening of the Garapan Public Market, which I had funded with a $200,000 earmark.

Lawmakers on the House Committee on Veterans’ Affairs – led by the highest-ranking enlisted soldier to ever serve in Congress – are calling on the VA to initiate research into the efficacy of medical cannabis. In a letter Thursday to VA Secretary David Shulkin, the lawmakers cited the country’s opioid crisis and the growing demand from veterans and major veterans service organizations that want cannabis available as a treatment option for chronic pain and post-traumatic stress disorder. -- Nikki Wentling, Stars and Stripes

This week, the House is expected to consider legislation to reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program, and provide funding for Community Health Centers and other expiring public health programs. This bill represents another partisan effort to undermine the Affordable Care Act (ACA), which will result in devastating cuts to public health programs.  After weeks of negotiations to reauthorize the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), Community Health Centers (CHCs) and other important public health programs, which have always been bipartisan priorities, the majority have decided to bring a partisan bill to the floor.  This bill will only further delay the reauthorization of these programs, many of which expired on September 30th. The bill passed out of the Energy and Commerce Committee at the beginning of October with no Democratic support.  Democrats in Committee instead offered a package that invests in our children and safety net providers, and does not sacrifice the nation’s health. Democrats have made it clear for weeks that the pay-fors in this bill are problematic. Rather than working toward a bipartisan agreement, the majority revised their bill to include even steeper cuts to public health programs.  This bill also seeks to cut $10.5 billion to the Prevention and Public Health Fund (PPHF), zeroing out the fund entirely from 2020 – 2026.  The Prevention Fund was created by the ACA to make national investments in prevention and public health, to improve health outcomes, to enhance health care quality, and reduce health care costs. It has been used to increase awareness of and access to preventive health services, such as cancer screenings, tobacco cessation and childhood vaccines – as well as concentrating on preventing chronic disease to help more Americans stay healthy. Eliminating these funds will have a devastating impact on public health initiatives at the federal, state and local levels, including the Northern Marianas.   While the majority are pushing for tax cuts for the wealthy that explode the deficit, when it comes to health coverage for children and low-income Americans, they are insisting that it be paid for at the cost of weakening our health care system and pushing other Americans off health insurance.  States have begun to use emergency funding, cut benefits, and will soon begin sending disenrollment notices to thousands of families if CHIP is not reauthorized.  The majority’s decision to advance a partisan bill rather than a compromise has very real consequences for families in the Marianas.

Whether it is working on the Veterans Affairs Committee marking legislations so they could move to the House floor for further and final action, or in roundtable listening sessions with Veterans Services Organizations (VSO), I remain active in highlighting the needs, and advocating for the programs to address those needs, for all our Marianas veterans.  And, as the only Micronesian in Congress, I always remember to also advocate for our comrades and veterans from the Freely Associated States (the Federated States of Micronesia, the Republic of the Marshall Islands and the Republic of Palau) who also served in the uniformed services.

Bill extends E-NAP for 5 years  I introduced H.R. 4216 on Thursday to extend the Enhanced Nutrition Assistance Program in the Marianas through 2023. E-NAP is the result of the $32.5 million I included for the Marianas in the 2014 Agricultural Act. The funding has allowed the Commonwealth government to add more households to the existing food stamp program and raise benefits. But funding ends this year, fiscal 2018, so more is needed to continue. So far, an additional 314 households have been added to E-NAP, or approximately 1,036 individuals. Benefits have gone up for a household of four on Saipan from $515 per month to $686. On Tinian, the increase was from $568 to $744. On Rota, benefits went from $719 to $897. Tinian and Rota receive higher benefits because of the higher cost of food there. I advocated for this benefit differential with the Food and Nutrition Service at the House Agriculture Committee and it went into effect in 2014. If enacted, H.R. 4216 would provide $42.5 million more for food aid in the Marianas.

Governor: Thanks for H.R. 339 support  I have advocated for a CW cut of just one for 2018—to 12,997. That would be consistent with what the Obama administration had been doing.  At the same time, I sent Governor Ralph DLG. Torres a letter of thanks this week for his strong support of H.R. 339, my bill increasing the number of CW permits available for the Marianas in 2017. President Trump signed it into law in August. Public Law 115-53 also blocks the use of CW permits for new construction work to protect local businesses unable to renew their legacy workers. And it adds extra money for training local workers. The Governor testified to the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee in April that the bill was “necessary and important.” And he agreed that “construction workers could be sourced through H2-B visas.” This could prove crucial, if the Trump administration deeply cuts CW permits for 2018. Many CW permits are now being used by temporary construction workers, who could get the H-2B visa instead.

Islanders are Americans, too. Six weeks after Hurricanes Irma and Maria struck, many in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are still without basic needs—electricity, food, water. Schools remain closed. Roads are not cleared. Just because Americans live in “territories” they must not be forgotten. To make that point I joined my Democratic colleagues on the Capitol steps on Thursday. Our nation needs to do better to help these islands recover.

Today, Veterans Day, we give thanks to the brave men and women who have put their lives on the line on our behalf. One of the best ways to thank our veterans is to ensure those who have served get good-paying jobs and fulfilling careers that enable them to provide for their families. That is why I requested a special waiver to sit on the House Veterans Affairs Committee in this Congress, because veterans in the Marianas are not getting all the services they earned from the Veterans Administration. I used my membership to successfully offer an amendment to H.R. 4243 requiring the VA to report back to the Committee on services to island veterans.  That is also why, early this year, working with Chairman Roe and Ranking Member Walz, I asked that the House Veterans Affairs Committee visit the Pacific territories and Commonwealth to meet with veterans and see for themselves how little services the VA provides to our veterans.  Today's Veterans Day (and every day), let's say a sincere thank you to the veterans in our lives. But I hope you'll join me in committing to do more — by hiring veterans, by supporting strong educational benefits for those who serve, and by helping the men and women of our military enjoy good-paying, fulfilling careers once they come home.  Happy Veterans Day!

Wind energy study okayed. Lowering electricity costs for families and businesses in the Marianas is a long-standing goal. So, when a national energy bill came before the Natural Resources Committee on Wednesday (above), I offered an amendment to include a study of offshore wind energy in the Marianas. If the study shows wind energy is feasible for electrical generation, then the SECURE American Energy Act, H.R. 4239, authorizes offshore leases to be offered. Chairman Rob Bishop (R-Utah) was kind enough to co-sponsor my amendment, which I wrote to cover American Samoa, too. Wind energy is a proven and cost-effective technology. A 2017 study by the investment firm Lazard found the cost of offshore wind to be $113 per MWh versus $197 for diesel generation. The 2013 Renewable Energy Integration Study, commissioned by the Commonwealth Utilities Corporation, predicted significant cost savings with the addition of renewable energy, including wind, to the CUC system.

IMPORTANT TRAVEL INFORMATION FOR NORTHERN MARIANAS RESIDENTS USING THEIR COMMONWEALTH ISSUED DRIVER'S LICENSE TO CLEAR TSA.  Passed by Congress in 2005, the REAL ID Act established minimum security standards for state-issued driver’s licenses and identification cards and prohibits federal agencies, like TSA, from accepting licenses and identification cards for official purposes from states that do not meet these standards.  Enforcement Dates Beginning January 22, 2018, driver’s licenses or state IDs issued by states that are not in compliance with the REAL ID Act and have not been granted an extension by DHS may not be used to fly within the U.S.  Beginning October 1, 2020, every traveler will need a REAL ID-compliant license or state ID or another acceptable form of identification to fly within the U.S.  When Flying… If your state is compliant:  • You may continue to use your state-issued driver’s license or ID to fly in the U.S. until October 1, 2020.   • Beginning October 1, 2020, you may only use a REAL ID compliant driver’s license or ID or another acceptable form of identification for domestic air travel. If your state is not compliant:  • Beginning January 22, 2018, you may continue to use your state-issued driver’s license or ID for domestic air travel only if your state has been granted an extension to the compliance deadline by DHS. If your state has not been granted an extension by DHS you may not use your state-issued driver’s license or ID for domestic air travel.  • Beginning October 1, 2020, you may not use your state-issued driver’s license or ID for domestic air travel.  REAL ID Enforcement: Northern Mariana Islands - UNDER REVIEW  Northern Mariana Islands is currently under review for a renewed extension from REAL ID enforcement.  DHS is currently reviewing extension requests from states with extensions that expired on October 10th, 2017.  DHS will update this page as these reviews are completed and new extensions are granted.  In the meantime, there will be no change in enforcement status for these states.  States will have a grace period until January 22, 2018, meaning that Federal agencies (including TSA) will continue to accept driver’s license and identification cards issued by these states in accordance with each agency’s policies.  Secure driver's licenses and identification documents are a vital component of a holistic national security strategy. Law enforcement must be able to rely on government-issued identification documents and know that the bearer of such a document is who he or she claims to be. REAL ID is a coordinated effort by the states and the Federal Government to improve the reliability and accuracy of state-issued identification documents, which should inhibit terrorists’ ability to evade detection by using fraudulent identification.

Rota Department of Lands and Natural Resources staff briefed me this week on their Rhinoceros Beetle Control Project. Rota Forester James Manglona discovered 20 adult beetles and many grubs of this invasive species when a coconut tree fell to the ground last month. DLNR now plans to set up an incident command to manage response and identify short-term resources that can be used over the next three months to stop this infestation from spreading.

Mount Carmel School Knights [and other high schools] develop apps for US Congressional Challenge. The Congressional App Challenge is a public effort to encourage kids to learn how to code, through annual district-wide competitions hosted by Members of Congress for their district. Students in participating districts code original applications for the chance to be selected for recognition by their member of Congress, win prizes, and have their work put on display in the Capitol in Washington, D.C. The district-wide competitions, now in their third year, take place from July through early November. The CAC is executed by the congressional staff of each participating district, and coordinated by the Congressional Internet Caucus and the non-governmental sponsor of the project, the Internet Education Foundation.

The pensions of millions of workers are under threat because of financial challenges facing several large multi-employer pension plans. If enough underfunded large plans fail to meet their obligations, it could crash the ability of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the federal agency that insures private-sector retirement plans nationwide, to provide backup payments that protect workers and retirees. On Wednesday, Chairman Tim Walberg (R-Michigan) and I, as ranking member of the House Subcommittee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, held a hearing in search of a solution to this complex financial crisis. It is not the fault of the workers or the retirees that their pension plans are on the brink of insolvency and that is why I have cosponsored, H.R, 4444, the Rehabilitation for Multi-employer Pensions Act.
Support firefighter programs

Maybe abandoning the hospital was the only choice, when our economy was in dire straits. But today the commonwealth is flush with cash.  Who gets a cut of that new money is a political decision. And, in my view, the health of our people — not to mention the education of our children — should not be the last to benefit from all the casino dollars the Legislature is handing out.  -- Congressman Kilili

Ornaments made by Mount Carmel School Students adorn the Northern Mariana Islands’ Christmas tree at President’s Park outside the White House. Our tree is one of 56 state and territory trees lining the “Pathway of Peace” around the National Christmas Tree. Many thanks to the MCS sophomore art students who made these ornaments under the direction of their teacher, Ms. May Ling Colombo. Go Knights!

Members of the Washington press corps met with Members of Congress to discuss employee leave after our Health, Employment, Labor and Pensions Subcommittee hearing on the issue Wednesday. Joining me were Rep. Rosa DeLauro (D-Connecticut), author of several bills expanding leave, and my Committee on Education and the Workforce colleagues Rep. Mark Takano (D-California) and Rep. Suzanne Bonamici (D-Oregon).

New federal court breaks ground. Construction of a new U.S. District Courthouse on Saipan broke ground on Thursday in Gualo Rai. In addition to meeting the operational and security requirements of a federal courthouse, the new facility will be the first Gold LEED-certified building in the Marianas, featuring landscaping, energy-efficient fixtures and lighting, water conservation technology, and other sustainability measures. The project, led by Marianas Management Co., a Joeten subsidiary, is expected to be completed in 2019.

Governor Ralph Dlg. Torres and his staff joined members of the Marianas business community for a meeting with Congressman Gregorio Kilili Camacho Sablan in Washington on Monday. All agreed that the Trump administration decision to cut the number of CW permits this year to 9,998 was not what they wanted. Looking ahead, Sablan asked the Governor to use his influence with the President to roll back a further cut to 4,999, already announced for next October. “In Congress, we are making good progress on consensus legislation that will ensure the Marianas economy has the labor it needs,” Sablan told the group. “But the Trump administration decision to cut to 4,999 permits in October cuts in half the time we have to act and makes it even more difficult to get a long-term solution into law. Short-term, the decision is also very bad for our economy.”

I appreciate that the members of the Northern Marianas Business Alliance Corporation (NMBA) took the time to meet with me during their lobbying trip to Washington. It is regrettable that NMBA came away from our meeting disappointed. Unfortunately, I cannot please everybody. But I do try to listen to the diverse and often conflicting voices that make up our community, many of which claim to speak in the best interests of all the people of the Marianas, and some of which sometimes say they want one thing and then change their minds later. It's not easy, but I signed on to work for the people of the Marianas.     NMBA, as I understand it, is the lobbying arm of the Governor's Strategic Economic Development Council. They came to Washington to advocate for their legislative proposals - a lengthy list of requests. Some of their requests I have already gotten done.      For example, they asked to bar construction workers from the CW program - that was accomplished with the enactment of H.R. 339, the Northern Marianas Economic Expansion Act, thanks in large part to the support of the Governor and the business community. They also asked for a report from the Government Accountability Office on the Marianas' economic prospects, including the impacts of ending the Commonwealth-Only Transitional Worker (CW) program. I requested that report last year, and GAO released the results of their study in May this year.   Some of NMBA's requests, however, will be difficult to sell in this anti-foreign worker, Republican administration and Congress. I have explained this reality to NMBA repeatedly. For example, increasing the CW cap to 18,000 (nearly doubling the number currently in effect) will be a very heavy lift, especially given the relatively high number of unemployed U.S. citizens and residents according to the Commonwealth government’s own data, and the Commonwealth government's record of waiving its own requirements for U.S. hires. Furthermore, splitting the Guam-CNMI visa waiver program, although desired by certain business interests in the Marianas, has nothing to do with an extension of the transition program, and will only distract from, and may even undermine, that effort. I have said this many times - in meetings with NMBA, their individual members, and members from other sectors of the community. Yet NMBA is still pushing for visa waiver bifurcation.   I want to be very clear that NMBA is not the only group I have met with to discuss labor issues. Over the last two years alone, I have also met with the Governor and his staff, the Governor's Strategic Economic Development Council, local legislators, mayors, the Chamber of Commerce, the Hotel Association of the Northern Mariana Islands, the Society of Human  Resource Management, small business owners who do not participate in any associations, U.S. workers and their advocates, CW workers and their advocates, lawyers, journalists, health care professionals, social workers, law enforcement officers, thought leaders, educators, students.    It is my job as Delegate to consult with the people I represent, to sort through their competing interests and concerns, to weigh the available data and facts on the ground, and to make the best decision that I can, based on all of these factors, about the way forward. It is also my job to take the best available information that I have to make our case in Washington, and work with my congressional colleagues to figure out what's possible, what can be achieved to improve the lives of the people I represent.      In Congress, we legislate. And in developing legislation, we negotiate and compromise. That's the nature of the work. Because for a measure to pass, we must have the support of at least 218 Members of the House and a minimum of 51 Senators, whose priorities and concerns may not be in line with our own. And because each Senator can block movement on a bill, the support of key Senators is critical to every legislative effort.   As I have said before in many meetings, press conferences, and news releases, I am now part of a bipartisan, bicameral working group that is developing legislation to carry the Marianas beyond 2019, when the current transition program expires. The working group is led by Senator Lisa Murkowski, who chairs the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, which has jurisdiction over the insular areas. The group is still agreeing on the limits that will shape this legislation.   I can say at this time that my priorities are two-fold: 1) to ensure that there is sufficient labor available to keep the Marianas economy moving forward; and 2) to ensure that the number of U.S. workers continues to increase over time. We have made some progress in recruiting, training, and hiring U.S. workers these past nine years since federal immigration law was extended to the Marianas, but as we know, as the data show, we still have a long way to go.   As I tried to explain to NMBA at my meeting on Monday, I am not at liberty to disclose the details of working group conversations that are, at this point, still preliminary, sensitive, and confidential. Building trusting relationships is critical to getting anything done in Congress. Everything I have been able to accomplish in Congress - from labor legislation to boosting funding for education, health care, infrastructure, and food assistance - has been through the strong relationships of trust that I have built on both sides of the aisle these past nine years.   I also explained that I have asked that the working group include the Governor in these talks. When the Chair decides to issue that invitation is not my call, but I understand the Governor’s legislative proposal was transmitted to the Chair some time ago.  I recognize and understand the anxiety in our community about the future, and the need for transparency about the work underway in Washington. I am doing my best to reach out to constituents across our community to make sure that I am hearing a broad range of perspectives. I am pushing to include the Governor in the working group. When legislation is introduced, I want to assure the people I represent that there will be a public hearing and ample opportunity for comment. In the meantime, although I regret that NMBA was not happy after their meeting with me this week, I will continue to welcome their feedback, as I welcome feedback from all constituents about the work I am doing for them.

This week, I wrote holiday greetings to our service members overseas through the U.S.O. and American Red Cross. I signed several banners to be sent to military bases overseas and wrote a few greeting cards to troops wishing them the warmest regards and thanking them for their sacrifice and service. Making an effort to thank them for their dedication to service is something very important to me this and every holiday season.

Helping NMC graduates get in-state tuition at four-year public universities in the U.S. was the purpose of my amendment to the Higher Education Act I offered during the marathon mark-up by the Education and the Workforce Committee on Tuesday. Although I was able to get two Republican votes, the rest of the majority members voted against the proposal.

Mount Carmel School alumni Ryan and Michael Ortizo visited their congressional office in Washington, DC on Wednesday. Ryan, who has a bachelor’s degree from New York University, is currently in his final year at the Virginia Commonwealth University School of Medicine. Michael is pursuing a degree in criminal justice at the University of Delaware. Thank you, Ortizo brothers, for visiting and for making us proud. Go, Knights!

$6.3M more for water, sewer CIP. Extra water and sewer CIP funds for the Marianas are not automatic. They have to be won every year in Congress during the appropriation process. We were successful at keeping the enhanced formula for island areas in place again this year, making it another $6.3 million for Marianas water and sewer infrastructure—$63 million in total during my time in office—money that would otherwise be added to users’ monthly CUC bill.
